This Is For the Birds

Time to go birding! Here are some bird-watching guides and tales.

Birding is an activity for any age, and any skill level.  Summer is one of the best times to work on your birding skills.  Award-winning author, illustrator, and ornithologist David Allen Sibley just released the second edition of The Sibley Field Guide to Birds of Eastern North America. This is your go-to guide for information about bird behavior, nesting patterns, habitats, conservation efforts, song descriptions, feeding habits, and coloration/identification examples. Sibley does an amazing job describing birds through both words and illustration.      

If you aren’t the most expert birder, have no fear, take a look at the aviary expedition tale of Bob Tarte.  Determined to become a skilled birder, Tarte shares his insights and humor in his book Feather Brained, as he journeys from place to place learning the best birding techniques.  His ultimate goal was to find a rare bird on his own.    

Feeling stuck?  Need to do something completely new?  Yearning for some outdoor time?  Well, quit your job, and consider following in the footsteps of Neil Hayward.  In his recently released memoir entitled Lost Among the Birds, Hayward chronicles his quest to find more birds than anyone else in one year.  Taking a break from the “working world” allowed Hayward to re-ignite his love for ornithology, and to find his true self.  Hayward is on the Board of Directors for the Brookline Bird Club (BBC), which is the biggest and one of the oldest of the many bird clubs in Massachusetts.

Learn about the birds in your backyard.  How many do you count at your bird feeder?  Do you recognize their coloring, their songs, and their feeding patterns?  Stan Tekiela has an excellent field guide to the Birds of Massachusetts.

Need someone to hold you accountable for your aviary learning?  Kids love a contest!  Include them in your love for and study of our feathered friends.  Challenge them to see how many birds they observe or how many fun facts they can learn about one species.  Encourage them to utilize the National Geographic’s Kids’ Ultimate Explorer Field Guide to Birds by Julie Beer.    

Both David Allen Sibley and Neil Hayward were recently at Brookline Booksmith.  In order not to miss other exciting nature-focused events at Booksmith, sign up for our e-newsletter or visit our events page!

Happy Birding!
